bestBHT.bht: Baptism is regarded as the burial of the former life, symbolically displayed through immersion. By being plunged under the water, believers declare their faith in the expiatory death of Christ for the forgiveness of past sins. Baptism serves as a picture of the change already wrought in the heart through faith, portraying the resurrection to new life in Christ. Emphasizing faith in God's energy as displayed in Christ's resurrection, baptism is a significant emblem of the believers' spiritual resurrection and the powerful operation of God in their souls.

Henry Alford: the process itself of baptism is regarded as the burial of the former life
the physical power exerted in Him is not only a pledge of the same physical power to be exerted in us, but a condition and assurance of a spiritual power already exerted in us
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Baptism is regarded as the burial of the old carnal life, to which the act of immersion symbolically corresponds; and in warm climates where immersion is safe, it is the mode most accordant with the significance of the ordinance.
Faith in God's mighty operation in raising again Jesus, is saving faith; and it is wrought in the soul by His same 'mighty working' whereby He 'raised Jesus from the dead'.
As His literal resurrection is the ground of the power put forth in our spiritual resurrection now, so it is a pledge of our literal resurrection hereafter.
Albert Barnes: Through the faith of the operation of God.
Marvin Vincent: The raising is not the resurrection to eternal life at Christ's second coming, but the moral resurrection to a new life.
The emphasis which is laid on faith in the resurrection.
Faith in God's energy as displayed in Christ's resurrection.
John Calvin: Christ, says he, accomplishes in us spiritual circumcision, not through means of that ancient sign, which was in force under Moses, but by baptism.
Baptism, therefore, is a sign of the thing that is presented to us, which while absent was prefigured by circumcision.

He takes this, however, for granted, that, inasmuch as it is impossible that believers should be severed from their head, the same power of God, which shewed itself in Christ, is diffused among them all in common.
Philip Schaff: The fellowship with Christ finds its sign and seal in the rite of baptism, which, as then administered, had its external resemblance to the burial and resurrection of Christ."
The passage shows that immersion was the mode in the Apostle’s mind; that he meant to represent it as the only mode is denied by most commentators.
Only through faith in such a God as able and willing to raise us up spiritually can we partake in this new life.
Archibald T. Robertson: For all who in the rite of baptism are plunged under the water, thereby declare that they put faith in the expiatory death of Christ for the pardon of their past sins."
In the symbol of baptism the resurrection to new life in Christ is pictured with an allusion to Christ's own resurrection and to our final resurrection.
Baptism gives a picture of the change already wrought in the heart 'through faith'.
John Gill: Christ having died for their sins, was laid in the grave, where he continued for a while, and then rose again; and as they were crucified with him, they were also buried with him...
Baptism being performed by immersion...is a very significant emblem of all this; it is a representation of the burial of Christ...
For the apostle's meaning is, that in baptism saints are risen with Christ, as well as in it buried with him...
John Wesley: The ancient manner of baptizing by immersion is as manifestly alluded to here, as the other manner of baptizing by sprinkling or pouring of water is."
But no stress is laid on the age of the baptized, or the manner of performing it, in one or the other; but only on our being risen with Christ, through the powerful operation of God in the soul.
It does not appear, that in all this St. Paul speaks of justification at all, but of sanctification altogether.

bhtAttempts.bht: In this verse, baptism is seen as a symbolic burial of our old ways, while emphasizing faith in God's power displayed through the resurrection of Jesus. By being submerged in water during baptism, believers declare their faith in the expiatory death of Christ. Baptism serves as a picture of the change already wrought in the heart through faith, portraying the resurrection to new life in Christ. Through the powerful operation of God, believers participate in this new life and the fellowship with Christ, symbolically represented through the rite of baptism.

Baptism is regarded as the burial of our former life, symbolically displayed by immersion. In this act, believers declare faith in the expiatory death of Christ for forgiveness. It serves as a picture of the change already wrought in the heart through faith, representing the resurrection to new life in Christ. The emphasis is on faith in God's mighty operation displayed in Jesus' resurrection, which becomes saving faith in the soul. Through the powerful operation of God, believers partake in this new life and fellowship with Christ.

Baptism is seen as the burial of our old carnal life, symbolically represented through immersion. Believers put faith in the expiatory death of Christ for the pardon of their past sins. It serves as a sign and seal of fellowship with Christ, portraying the new life in Him. The emphasis lies on faith in God's power displayed in Christ's resurrection. Through baptism, believers are not only buried with Christ, but also risen with Him, sharing in the spiritual power already exerted in them.

Baptism is regarded as the burial of the former life, symbolically displayed through immersion. By being plunged under the water, believers declare their faith in the expiatory death of Christ for the forgiveness of past sins. Baptism serves as a picture of the change already wrought in the heart through faith, portraying the resurrection to new life in Christ. Emphasizing faith in God's energy as displayed in Christ's resurrection, baptism is a significant emblem of the believers' spiritual resurrection and the powerful operation of God in their souls.

Baptism is regarded as the burial of the old carnal life, symbolically depicted through immersion. By plunging under the water, believers affirm their faith in the expiatory death of Christ for the forgiveness of sins. It serves as a representation of the change already wrought in the heart through faith, picturing the resurrection to new life in Christ. Emphasizing faith in God's mighty operation displayed in Christ's resurrection, baptism is a powerful symbol of the believers' spiritual resurrection and the transformative work of God.
